newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Hong Kong stocks close soft after see-saw day.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong stocks close soft after see-saw day.

text.p: Hong Kong stocks closed weaker on Monday after a volatile day which saw the Hang Seng Index hitting a new record high, before retreating on profit-taking and nervousness over China-related red chips, brokers said.
The Hang Seng Index closed down 133.13 points, or 0.88 percent, at 15,021.23.
Turnover was HK$26.33 billion (US$3.4 billion), marginally down on Friday's record figure of HK$26.6 billion.
Earlier in the day, the Hang Seng Index had touched a new record high, rising 167 points to 15,322 as investors showed their bullishness on the July 1 handover to China.
"(It's) very volatile, and very confused," said James Osborne, sales director at ING Barings.
The day was characterised by massive volatility and capital flows, but one broker predicted further short-term record highs because "that's what everybody wants".
A broker with a European institution said much of the liquidity was flowing in from China ahead of the handover, but the flows were short-term.
Hong Kong reverts to Chinese rule after more than 150 years of British rule.

Hang Seng Bank Ltd helped drag the market down, as it slid HK$5.50 to HK$104.00, partly on profit-taking after speculation of Chinese interests taking a stake in the bank had earlier pushed it to a new high on Friday.

The market was also dampened by China's State Council announcement on Friday that transferral of domestic assets into China-controlled firms overseas would require government approval if the purpose was to inject into a listed vehicle.
Brokers said the announcement was prompting a re-appraisal of red chips, with investors focusing on their fundamentals rather than on potential future asset injections.
Red chips are companies which are Hong Kong-based, but China-controlled.

Red chip Beijing Enterprises Holding Ltd, usually a darling among investors, was one of the biggest losers, slipping HK$1.60 to HK$47.60, and Shanghai Industrial Holdings Ltd lost HK$1.50 to HK$43.00.
HSBC Holdings Plc lost HK$3.00, partly on the back of the falls in its subsidiary, Hang Seng Bank.

Property companies also slipped, with Sun Hung Kai Properties Ltd losing HK$1.50 to HK$93.75, Henderson Land Development Co Ltd easing HK$1.75 to HK$70.50 and New World Development Co Ltd dropping HK$1.10 to HK$47.40.
